results.title: Mother earth
results.creator_credit: L. Scott-Ehrenberg, Charles Blanks and Rural Bank of New South Wales
results.brief_description: Diary of Brian Gordon. Brian Gordon and his younger brother Michael, Sydneysiders, embark on a trip to rural New South Wales. Taken by the peace and lifestyle of the farming districts, both regret their imminent return to the city. But as luck would have it, Brian meets and falls in love with an orphaned country girl, Marian. Fortunately Brian is able to arrange a Rural Bank of New South Wales loan to assist himself and the cash-strapped Marian save her farm. A patriotic and heroic view of the idealised bush of a by-gone era. NB: A promotional film for the Rural Bank of New South Wales.
results.creator_credit_for_label: L. Scott-Ehrenberg, Charles Blanks and Rural Bank of New South Wales

results.title: Mother cat and her baby skunks
results.creator_credit: Milan Herzog and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: A mother cat finds three baby skunks in the woods that have lost their mother. She adopts them and induces them to return to the farmyard where she has three kittens of her own. The baby skunks and kittens are shown developing side by side. The farm dog lives in harmony with the cat and helps her to protect the babies.

results.title: Mother and son. No. 2
results.brief_description: Ruth Cracknell and Gary McDonald play Maggie and Arthur. Maggie appears to be losing her memory but retains enough to take full advantage of having her younger son, Arthur, living at home with her and on call for her needs whether he likes it or not. This program includes the episodes, “The Card Game”; “The Promotion”; “The Funeral”.

results.title: Mother and son. No. 1 (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Geoffrey Portmann, ABC-TV (Australia) and Geoffrey Atherden
results.brief_description: The money : Maggie has been saving up her pension cheques and Arthur needs to find them, but where are they? “The aunt” : Arthur invites Maggie’s sister Lorna for a visit. At first all goes well but then Lorna dares to pick some of Maggie’s flowers… “The accident” : Someone drops a typewriter on Arthur’s foot and he’s stuck at home being nursed by Maggie! Stars Ruth Cracknell and Garry McDonald with Henri Szeps and Judy Morris.

results.title: Mother and child
results.creator_credit: Francis Fuchs, Eurfron Gwynne Jones and BBC-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Children Growing Up”.
Explores the changing relationship between mother and child from birth to school age. Considers two common family crises involving separation - when either mother or child goes to hospital and the arrival of a new baby. Narrated by Hugh David.

results.title: Mother & Son - The Picnic
results.brief_description: Ruth Cracknell and Gary McDonald are brilliant as Maggie and Arthur. Maggie appears to be losing her memory, but still knows how to enjoy life. Arthur yearns to be free from the responsibility of caring for his mother, but he’s stuck, and Maggie makes the most of it. This tape includes three episodes: The Picnic ; The Last Will and The Cruise.

results.title: Mother's day
results.brief_description: A humorous, satirical and overwhelmingly skilful experimental film by San Francisco poet James Broughton who has discarded the conventions and cliches of film making. Accepting the potentialities of the medium to manipulate both time and space, he brings past and present head-on as he regards with adult feelings his childhood, family and friends. Grown-ups romp like children, and by their magnified infantilism playfully underscore such basic traits as sadism, sensuality and egocentricity. While mother tuns out to be the biggest infant of them all, blindly holding to her ideal of beauty, blind to its disastrous effect upon her entire family. The undertones of this film are disturbing and Broughton has knowingly added to that sense of disturbance by introducing into it a range of objects that appear symbolic. Broughton, however, attempts to expose the audience to a total visual experience, that is poetic and not merely a mystic maze of hidden symbolic meanings. This exploration of an artist’s world of memory, imagination and perception is among the most challenging experimental films produced in America during this period. Photography by Frank Stauffacher.

results.title: Moses Coady
results.creator_credit: Kent Martin, F Whitman Trecartin, Rex Tasker and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: The film is about Moses Coady, who was called many things in his lifetime, but who proved to be the most effective social reformer Canada has known. He went into the villages, organized the people into study groups, helped them set up credit unions and co-operatives, and freed them from the semi-feudal conditions they lived in. Today, people from all over the world come to study his methods at the Coady International Institute in Antigonish, Nova Scotia. Voice and narration: Joan Orenstein.
